[[File:Resistin radicatz.jpg|thumb|320px|right|The Resistin Radicatz, a radical cheerleading group, do a cheer in front of [[AFL-CIO]] headquarters in Washington before joining the [[Million Worker March]] at the Lincoln Memorial.]]
'''Radical cheerleading''' is a form of [[cheerleading]] performed at demonstrations that combines elements of [[non-violent direct action]] and [[street theater]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Lee|first=Rosa|title=Why Feminists Are Wrong: How Transsexuals Prove Gender Is Not a Social Construction|year=2006|publisher=Xlibris Corp.|location=Philadelphia|isbn=978-1-4257-1467-3|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=hoOJX3JWB0QC&lpg=PA26&ots=-Q0QxZFo5L&dq=radical%20cheerleaders&pg=PA26#v=onepage&q=radical%20cheerleaders&f=false|page=26}}</ref> It originated in 1996<ref>{{cite book|last=Bobel|first=Chris|title=New Blood: Third-Wave Feminism and the Politics of Menstruation|year=2010|publisher=Rutgers University Press|location=New Brunswick, N.J.|isbn=978-0-8135-4953-8|pages=121-124|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=B1326g__TUEC&lpg=PA121&ots=AQC2yGEHzc&dq=radical%20cheerleaders&pg=PA121#v=onepage&q=radical%20cheerleaders&f=false}}</ref> in [[Miami]], [[Florida]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Radical Cheerleaders Raise Ruckus |date=November 14, 2003 |accessdate=September 7, 2009 |first=Bootie |last=Cosgrove-Mather |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/11/14/national/main583821.shtml |work=CBS News|quote=Aimee Jennings, who now lives in New York, said inspiration struck after demonstrations at the [[1996 Democratic National Convention]] in Chicago}}</ref> and there are now many radical cheerleading squads in the [[United States]] as well as [[Canada]] and [[Europe]]. Radical cheerleaders reappropriate the aesthetics of cheerleading, sometimes in an ironic fashion, and use [[cheering|cheers]] that promote [[feminism]] and [[left-wing politics|left-wing]] causes.<ref>{{cite book|last=Grindstaff|first=Laura Anne|title=Encyclopedia of Gender and Society|year=2009|publisher=SAGE|location=Los Angeles|isbn=978-1-4129-0916-7 |chapter=Cheerleading: The Gender Politics of Contemporary Cheerleading |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=_nyHS4WyUKEC&lpg=PT158&ots=h1VYipd5FH&dq=radical%20cheerleaders&pg=PT158#v=onepage&q=radical%20cheerleaders&f=false|page=126}}</ref> Radical cheerleaders subvert gender norms through costuming and may be male, [[transgender]] or non-gender identified.<ref>{{cite book|first=Natalie Guice |last=Adams |first2=Pamela |last2=Bettis |title=Cheerleader!: An American Icon|year=2003|publisher=Palgrave|location=New York|isbn=978-1-4039-6184-6|pages=36-39|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ncXeMQUMtPgC&lpg=PP1&ots=usJqypZj99&dq=%22radical%20cheerleading%22&pg=PA36#v=onepage&q=%22radical%20cheerleading%22&f=false}}</ref> Feminist magazine director Lisa Jervis places radical cheerleading within a tradition of playful feminist comment on popular culture.<ref>{{Cite news | title = The End of Feminism's Third Wave: The cofounder of Bitch says goodbye | work = Ms. Magazine | accessdate = 2012-01-24 | year = 2004 | url = http://www.msmagazine.com/winter2004/thirdwave.asp }}</ref>
Radical cheerleaders often perform at [[Demonstration (people)|demonstrations]] and will lead protest chants.<ref>{{cite book|last=Atkinson|first=Joshua D.|title=Alternative Media and Politics of Resistance: A Communication Perspective|year=2010|publisher=Peter Lang|location=New York|isbn=978-1-4331-0517-3|pages=126-128|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=aR5uGYkTj5UC&lpg=PA127&ots=HVwsoN399_&dq=%22radical%20cheerleading%22&pg=PA127#v=onepage&q=%22radical%20cheerleading%22&f=false}}</ref> They also often perform at feminist and other radical festivals and events. Radical cheerleading is used at demonstrations to promote a radical message in a media-friendly, people-friendly way. It is also used to support the actions of other [[activists]] who put themselves at physical risk and to denounce infiltrators and opponents.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} Radical cheerleaders may also perform on stage at music venues, to bring political issues (as well as entertainment) to an unsuspecting crowd. Chicago's Lickity Split cheerleaders frequently used this tactic.
One of the most notable radical cheerleading appearances was at the [[March for Women's Lives]] in [[Washington, DC]] on April 25, 2004. The cheerleaders had their own feeder march and bloc within the larger march with over 2,000 participants. The group's purpose was to raise awareness about the lack of access low-income women have to [[abortion]] clinics.
Radical cheerleaders are often [[anti-authoritarian]] and [[anti-capitalist]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} Their cheers are usually written from scratch or by rewriting the words of popular and historic songs. Radical cheerleaders dress in diverse ways but often wear a combination of [[red]] or [[pink]] and [[black]].
Some radical cheerleaders make [[pom-pom]]s using garbage bags by folding them in half, tying off one side with a rubber band and then cutting strips from the other end.
